query: For agricultural landscapes, what are the most effective interventions for creating and managing aquatic habitats for amphibians?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several interventions are effective for creating and managing aquatic habitats for amphibians in agricultural landscapes. Creating ponds for amphibians is highly effective, with 28 studies showing that amphibians used some or all created ponds, and amphibians established stable populations in 50-100% of created ponds (Action 869). Created ponds were used or colonized by up to 15 naturally colonizing species and up to 10 species that reproduced (Action 869). Creating wetlands also shows similar effectiveness, with created wetlands having similar numbers of amphibian species and abundance as natural wetlands, and 4 to 15 amphibian species using or colonizing the wetlands (Action 880). Pond restoration is effective for increasing amphibian populations, with studies showing that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and breeding success (Action 878). Wetland restoration similarly increased numbers of amphibian species and established breeding populations, with restored wetlands being colonized by 3 to 8 amphibian species (Action 879). Managing water levels is important, with studies showing that maintaining pond water levels increased natterjack toad populations and enabled successful breeding by dusky gopher frogs (Action 833). Pond deepening, de-silting and re-profiling resulted in establishment of breeding populations and increased amphibian populations (Action 817). Managing ditches under agri-environment schemes resulted in significantly higher numbers of amphibian species and abundance compared to conventional management (Action 749). Removing or controlling fish by drying out ponds increased numbers of amphibian species and breeding success (Action 826). Effectiveness of these interventions was affected by factors including pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds, presence of fish, wetland design, water levels, and proximity to source ponds (Actions 869, 880, 879).

Twenty-eight studies investigated the colonization of created ponds by amphibians in general (rather than by targeted species, which are discussed below). All of the studies found that amphibians used some or all created ponds.
Nine site comparison studies (including seven replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Spain, the UK and USA compared amphibian numbers in created and natural ponds. Five found that numbers of species or breeding species were similar or higher in created ponds, and numbers of ponds colonized were similar. Four found that species composition differed, and comparisons between abundance of individual species, juvenile productivity and size at metamorphosis differed depending on species. One found that numbers of species were similar or lower depending on the permanence of created water bodies. One found that populations in created ponds were less stable.
One review and two replicated, before-and-after studies in Denmark and the USA found that amphibians established stable populations in 50–100% of created ponds. Six replicated studies (including one randomized study) in France, the Netherlands, UK and USA found that amphibians used 64–100% and reproduced in 64–68% of created ponds, or used 8–100% and reproduced in 2–62% depending on species. One review and 15 studies (including 12 replicated studies, one of which was randomized) in Europe and the USA found that created ponds were used or colonized by up to 15 naturally colonizing species, up to 10 species that reproduced, as well as by captive-bred amphibians. Five replicated studies (including three site comparison studies) in Denmark, Estonia, France, Italy and the USA found that pond creation, and restoration in three cases, maintained and increased amphibian populations or increased numbers of species.
Seven studies (including one review) in Austria, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and USA found that use or colonization of or reproductive success in created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds and presence of fish."

Two of the studies found that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower abundance and different communities compared to natural wetlands. One site comparison study in the USA found that created wetlands had similar numbers of species to adjacent forest. One global review and two site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA combined created and restored wetlands and compared them to natural wetlands and found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance was higher or similar, or higher in 54% of studies and similar in 35% of studies reviewed compared to natural wetlands. Three site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA found that certain amphibian species were only found in created or natural wetlands. 
One before-and-after study in Australia found that captive-bred green and golden bell frog tadpoles released into a created wetland did not establish a self-sustaining population.
Five studies (including two replicated studies) in Kenya and the USA that investigated colonization of created wetlands found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized the wetlands. One global review and three studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and amphibian abundance in created wetlands were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands."

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of pond restoration for amphibians.
One replicated, before-and-after study in Denmark found that pond restoration had mixed effects on European tree frog population numbers depending on site. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration did not increase great crested newt populations. Six replicated, before-and-after studies (including one controlled and one site comparison study) in Denmark, Estonia, Italy and the UK found that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and ponds with breeding success. One found that numbers of species did not increase. Two before-and-after studies (including one replicated study) in Estonia found that pond restoration, along with terrestrial habitat management, maintained or increased populations of natterjack toads. One systematic review in the UK found that there was no conclusive evidence that mitigation, which often included pond restoration, resulted in self-sustaining great crested newt populations.
One small, replicated study in the USA found that pond restoration had mixed effects on spotted salamander hatching success depending on restoration method.
One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that restoration increased the number of ponds used by breeding natterjack toads. One replicated study in Sweden found that following restoration green toads only reproduced in one of 10 ponds. Three before-and-after studies (including one replicated, controlled study) in Denmark and Italy found that restored and created ponds were colonized by 1–7 species, with 6–65% of ponds colonized and 35% used for breeding."
}

Seventeen studies investigated the effectiveness of wetland restoration for amphibians.
Ten site comparison studies (including eight replicated studies) in Canada and the USA compared amphibian numbers in restored and natural wetlands. Eight found that amphibian abundance, numbers of species and species composition were similar. Two found that the number of species or abundance was lower and species composition different in restored wetlands. One found that restored wetlands were used more or less depending on the habitat surrounding natural wetlands. One global review found that in 89% of cases, restored and created wetlands had similar or higher amphibian abundance or numbers of species to natural wetlands.
Seven of nine studies (including six site comparison and/or replicated studies) in Canada, Taiwan and the USA found that wetland restoration increased numbers of amphibian species, with breeding populations establishing in some cases. Three found that numbers of species or abundance did not increase with restoration. Two found mixed effects, with restoration maintaining or increasing abundance of individual species. Three replicated studies (including two site comparison studies) in the USA found that numbers of species in restored wetlands were affected by wetland size, proximity to source ponds and seasonality, but not wetland age.
Three studies (including two replicated, site comparison studies) in Taiwan and the USA found that restored wetlands were colonized by three to eight amphibian species. One before-and-after study in the USA found that three target species did not recolonize restored wetlands."
}

query: What interventions are available for creating or providing shelter habitats for amphibians, such as refuges or hibernation sites?
relevant_summary: Several interventions are available for creating or providing shelter habitats for amphibians. Creating artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites has been tested, with one study in the UK finding that providing artificial hibernacula, along with other terrestrial habitat management, maintained populations of great crested newts (Action 759). Another study found that created hibernacula were used by common frog and smooth newts, but not great crested newts, and four amphibian species were found close to hibernacula at two of three sites (Action 759). Creating refuges involves adding coarse woody debris to forest floors, which showed mixed results - two studies found no effect on the number of amphibian species or overall abundance but had mixed effects on abundance of individual species, while restoration that included reintroducing coarse woody debris to the forest floor increased frog species (Action 772). Studies also found that artificial refugia were used by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders, although few were used for breeding (Action 772). One before-and-after study found that creating refugia for great crested newts, along with other interventions, maintained four populations (Action 772). Regarding coarse woody debris in forests, studies found mixed effects - one study showed that the overall response of amphibians was more negative where woody debris was retained, but migrating amphibians used clearcuts where woody debris was retained more than where it was removed (Action 843). Additionally, survival of juvenile amphibians was significantly higher in piles of woody debris than in open areas within clearcut forest (Action 843). For captive breeding, providing particular enclosure furniture including rotting logs and hollow bamboo pipes promoted egg laying in frogs, and housing frogs in enclosures with more calling, perching and laying sites led to successful breeding (Action 1876).

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of creating artificial refuges, hibernacula and aestivation sites on reptile populations. Three studies were in each of the UK and Australia, two were in New Zealand and one was in each of the USA, Spain and Italy.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One controlled, before-and-after study in Spain found that areas with refuge logs had higher reptile species richness than areas without refuges.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (1 study): One controlled, before-and-after study in Spain found that areas with refuge logs had a higher abundance of reptiles than areas without refuges.
Reproductive success (1 study): One study in the UK found that after translocating adders to an artificial hibernaculum, there was evidence of successful reproduction.
Survival (1 study): One randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in New Zealand found that in areas with artificial refuges, survival of McCann’s skinks was similar to areas without refuges.

BEHAVIOUR (9 STUDIES)

Use (9 studies): Nine studies (including one replicated, controlled study and one randomized, controlled study) in the USA, the UK, Australia, New Zealand and Italy found that artificial refuges were used by reptiles, common lizards, adders, common geckos, species of skinks, and by an ocellated lizard to lay a clutch of eggs. Four of the studies also found that some reptiles showed a preference for refuges with certain designs or construction materials."
}

query: What factors and interventions have influenced the success of natterjack toad conservation projects in the UK?
relevant_summary:
Habitat protection has shown significant benefits for natterjack toad conservation in the UK, with populations better protected at sites with statutory habitat protection compared to unprotected areas (action ID 820). Translocation programs have been particularly successful, with studies finding that translocated natterjack toad eggs, tadpoles, juveniles or adults established breeding populations in 30-70% of cases, with re-establishing toads on dune or saltmarsh habitat being more successful than on heathland (action ID 859). Multiple translocations of wild rather than captive-bred toads showed better results (action ID 859).

Pond creation has proven highly effective, with studies showing that pond creation significantly increased natterjack toad populations or maintained/increased populations at 75% of sites (action ID 866). However, created ponds had lower tadpole mortality from desiccation but higher mortality from predation by invertebrates compared to natural ponds (action ID 866). Vegetation clearance has been important for maintaining and increasing natterjack toad populations and increased occupancy by natterjack toads (action ID 761).

Water chemistry management through adding limestone to reduce acidification has shown mixed results - it resulted in establishment of translocated populations and increased breeding activity in some cases, but also caused high tadpole mortality and pond abandonment in others (action ID 748). Grazing management studies found that grazed plots did not have higher natterjack toad abundance than ungrazed plots, though habitat management including reintroduction of grazing maintained or increased populations (action ID 780).

Public awareness campaigns combined with other interventions have contributed to conservation success, increasing numbers of natterjack toads and creating 1,023 ponds for amphibians (action ID 831). Pond management through deepening and re-profiling, combined with other interventions, has increased natterjack toad populations (action ID 817).

query: What are the general outcomes and challenges associated with captive breeding programs for different amphibian groups like frogs, toads, and salamanders?
relevant_summary:
Captive breeding programs for amphibians show varied outcomes across different groups. For frogs, 23 of 33 studies found that amphibians produced eggs in captivity, with 17 studies finding captive-bred frogs were raised successfully to hatching, tadpoles, froglets or adults (Action 835). However, seven studies found mixed results with only 17-50% of captive populations reproducing successfully, and some species were difficult to maintain or raise to adults (Action 835). Specific survival rates for frogs included 30-88% of eggs hatching, 75% survival to metamorphosis, 17-51% survival as froglets, and 50-90% survival to adults (Action 835).

For salamanders, 4 of 6 studies found that eggs were produced successfully in captivity, with captive-bred salamanders raised to yearlings, larvae or adults (Action 838). However, egg production depended on tank habitat and was more successful in semi-natural compared to laboratory conditions (Action 838). One review found that four salamander species bred successfully but slimy salamanders produced eggs that did not hatch (Action 838). Japanese giant salamander eggs showed 60% survival to hatching in captivity (Action 838).

Several challenges affect breeding success across amphibian groups. Reproductive success depends on environmental factors like temperature and simulated wet/dry seasons (Action 835). Egg and tadpole development is affected by parental care, density, and temperature (Action 835). For salamanders, larval development, body condition and survival are affected by water temperature, density and whether raised under laboratory or semi-natural conditions (Action 838).

Breeding success can be enhanced through proper enclosure design. Adding rotting logs, hollow bamboo pipes and varied substrates promoted egg laying in frogs (Action 1876), and providing more calling, perching and laying sites along with simulated seasons encouraged breeding (Action 1876). Using surrogate species to refine husbandry techniques before working with target species promoted successful breeding of critically endangered frogs (Action 1862).

Hormone treatments show mixed results, with 9 of 10 studies finding that treatment stimulated sperm production in males, but female responses varied with only 30-71% producing viable eggs (Action 883). When hormone-induced eggs were successfully obtained, five studies found they could be raised to tadpoles, toadlets or froglets, though some studies found most toads died before or after hatching (Action 883).

Release success rates indicate that 41% of captive-bred amphibian release programs showed evidence of breeding in the wild for multiple generations, 29% showed some evidence of breeding, and 12% showed evidence of survival following release (Action 871). Head-started amphibians showed better outcomes, with six of 10 studies finding that released individuals established breeding populations or increased existing populations (Action 881).

{
  "action_id": "835",
  "action_title": "Captive breeding frogs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirty-three studies investigated the success of breeding frogs in captivity.
Twenty-three of 33 studies, three of which were reviews and 30 replicated studies, across the world found that amphibians produced egg in captivity, in four cases by captive-bred females. Seven found mixed results, with some species of frogs or 17–50% of captive populations  reproducing successfully in captivity, but with other species difficult to maintain or raise to adults. One found that frogs did not breed successfully in captivity and another that all breeding frogs died. Seventeen of the studies found that captive-bred frogs were raised successfully to hatching, tadpoles, froglets or adults in captivity. One found that froglet survival was low and another that three species were not successfully raised to adulthood.
Four replicated studies (including one small study) in,Canada, Fiji, Hong Kong and Italy found that 30–88% of eggs hatched or survival to metamorphosis was 75%, as froglets was 17–51% or to adults was 50–90% in captivity.
One review and four replicated studies (including two small studies) in Germany, Italy and the USA found that reproductive success of frogs in captivity depended on temperature or a simulated wet and dry season, but not on whether frogs were housed in high or low maintenance facilities. Three replicated studies (including one small study) in Germany, Australia and Canada found that egg or tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature."
}

{
  "action_id": "881",
  "action_title": "Head-start amphibians for release",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-two studies head-started amphibians from eggs and monitored them after release.
Six of 10 studies (including five replicated studies) in Denmark, Spain, the UK and USA and a global review found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations or increased populations of frogs or toads. Two found mixed results with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed or at two of four sites. Two found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population. For five of the studies, release of captive-bred individuals, translocation or habitat management were also carried out.
Nine of 10 studies (including nine replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Europe and the USA found that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs or adults metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year or bred successfully. One found adult survival was 1–17% over four years and one found limited breeding following the release of adults.
Four replicated studies in Australia, the UK and USA found that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis was greater and time to metamorphosis shorter in head-started compared to wild animals. One replicated study in Canada found that young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than those in the wild. One replicated study in Australia found that corroboree frog tadpoles released earlier had higher survival, but metamorphosed two weeks later than those released a month later.
Three studies (including one replicated study) in the USA only provided results for head-starting in captivity. Two found that Houston toad eggs could be captive-reared to tadpoles, but only one successfully reared adults. Three studies (including two replicated studies) in Canada and the USA found that during head-starting, amphibian growth rate, size, stress levels and survival was affected by the amount of protein provided, housing density or enclosure location. One found that mass, stress levels and survival were not affected by the amount of food or habitat complexity."

However, egg production depended on tank habitat and was more successful in semi-natural compared to laboratory conditions (Action 838). One review found that four salamander species bred successfully but slimy salamanders produced eggs that did not hatch (Action 838). Japanese giant salamander eggs showed 60% survival to hatching in captivity (Action 838).

Adding rotting logs, hollow bamboo pipes and varied substrates promoted egg laying in frogs (Action 1876), and providing more calling, perching and laying sites along with simulated seasons encouraged breeding (Action 1876). Using surrogate species to refine husbandry techniques before working with target species promoted successful breeding of critically endangered frogs (Action 1862).

query: As an alternative to creating entirely new ponds, what actions can be taken to restore or enhance existing water bodies for amphibians?
relevant_summary: Several actions can be taken to restore or enhance existing water bodies for amphibians as alternatives to creating new ponds. Pond restoration is a key approach, with studies showing it can increase numbers of amphibian species, maintain or increase populations, or increase pond occupancy and breeding success (action 878). Specific restoration techniques include deepening, de-silting or re-profiling ponds, which has resulted in establishment of breeding populations of great crested newts and translocated garlic toads, and increased populations of common frogs and tree frogs (action 817). Water level regulation is another important management practice that can increase natterjack toad populations, maintain newt populations, and enable successful breeding by dusky gopher frogs (action 833). Canopy management through removing tree canopy to reduce pond shading has helped establish breeding populations of translocated garlic toads (action 758). Chemical treatments to address water quality include adding lime to water bodies to reduce acidification, which has resulted in establishment of translocated natterjack toad populations, increased larval and egg survival of moor frogs and common frogs, and temporarily increased breeding by natterjack toads (action 748). Physical protection measures such as excluding domestic animals or wild hogs by fencing can increase larval abundance and abundance of green frog metamorphs, and has increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads when combined with other pond restoration activities (action 746). Removing specific aquatic plants is also mentioned as a management technique (action 815).

query: Which vegetation management practices are most likely to benefit amphibian populations, and which are likely to be ineffective or harmful?
relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, several vegetation management practices show beneficial effects for amphibian populations. Vegetation clearance along with other habitat management increased numbers of frog species and increased, stabilized or maintained populations of natterjack toads in Australia, Estonia and the UK (Action 761). Additionally, vegetation clearance resulted in increased occupancy by natterjack toads (Action 761). However, vegetation clearance maintained great crested newt populations for the first six years but not in the longer term (Action 761).

Habitat management that included reintroduction of grazing increased green toad populations, maintained or increased natterjack toad populations and maintained common toad populations in Denmark, Estonia and the UK (Action 780). Pond restoration that included livestock exclusion increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads (Action 746). Spotted salamander hatching success increased following a prescribed forest fire (Action 877).

Some practices showed mixed or limited effects. Prescribed forest fires had no effect on amphibian abundance or numbers of species in eight of 14 studies, while four found mixed effects depending on species, species and year or season of burn, three found increases in amphibian abundance or numbers of species, and one found decreased abundance (Action 877). Grazed plots did not have higher abundance of natterjack toads than ungrazed plots and had lower abundance of common toads (Action 780). Excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase numbers of amphibian species or overall abundance but did increase larval abundance and abundance of green frog metamorphs (Action 746). Excluding cattle from ponds did not increase numbers of eggs or larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs (Action 746).

query: What key factors are associated with the success or failure of amphibian colonization and breeding in newly created ponds?
relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, several key factors are associated with amphibian colonization and breeding success in newly created ponds. Pond age affects use and colonization, with one study finding that survival of translocated Oregon spotted frogs increased with increasing age of created ponds (Action 865). Distance to existing ponds is a critical factor, as use or colonization of created ponds was affected by distance to existing ponds (Action 869), and numbers of species in restored wetlands were affected by proximity to source ponds (Action 879). The surrounding landscape and habitat context influences success, with colonization affected by surrounding landscape (Action 869) and numbers of amphibian species and abundance affected by surrounding habitat (Action 880).

Water permanence is important, with studies finding that colonization was affected by pond permanence (Action 869), and that numbers of species were similar or lower depending on the permanence of created water bodies (Action 869). Vegetation cover influences success, as use or colonization was affected by vegetation cover (Action 869), and amphibian abundance in created wetlands was affected by vegetation (Action 880). Fish presence is a major factor affecting breeding success, with amphibian abundance affected by fish presence (Action 880), and studies showing that draining ponds to eliminate fish increased numbers of amphibian species (Action 826) and increased breeding success of frog or newt species (Action 826).

Pond design characteristics influence colonization, with amphibian abundance in created wetlands affected by wetland design (Action 880). Water levels are significant, as amphibian abundance was affected by water levels (Action 880), and maintaining pond water levels enabled successful breeding (Action 833). Overall colonization rates vary significantly, with studies showing amphibians used 64-100% and reproduced in 64-68% of created ponds, or used 8-100% and reproduced in 2-62% depending on species (Action 869).

query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of different direct treatments for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis?
relevant_summary: Evidence for direct treatments for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis shows varying effectiveness across different approaches. Antifungal treatments show the strongest evidence, with twelve of 16 studies finding that antifungal treatment cured or increased survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis, while four studies found that treatments did not cure chytridiomycosis but reduced infection levels or had mixed results (action 882). Specifically, six of eight studies testing itraconazole found it effective at curing amphibians of chytridiomycosis, with one study finding it reduced infection levels and one finding mixed effects (action 882). However, six studies found that specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians (action 882). Temperature treatment demonstrates effectiveness, with four of five studies finding that increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis, though one study found that heat treatment at 30-35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs (action 770). Antifungal skin bacteria or peptides show mixed results, with three of four studies finding that adding antifungal bacteria to the skin of salamanders or frogs exposed to chytrid fungus did not reduce chytridiomycosis infection rate or death, while one study found it prevented infection and death (action 764). One study found that adding antifungal skin bacteria to soil significantly reduced chytridiomycosis infection rate of red-backed salamanders, and three studies found that adding antifungal skin bacteria to chytrid infected amphibians reduced weight loss (action 764). Treatment with antimicrobial skin peptides before or after infection did not significantly increase survival of common toads (action 764). Field treatment approaches show limited success, with one study finding that treating wild midwife toads with fungicide, along with pond drying, reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis (action 767). Immunization showed no effectiveness, with one study finding that vaccinating mountain yellow-legged frogs with formalin-killed chytrid fungus did not significantly reduce chytridiomycosis infection rate or mortality (action 765).

Antifungal skin bacteria or peptides show mixed results, with three of four studies finding that adding antifungal bacteria to the skin of salamanders or frogs exposed to chytrid fungus did not reduce chytridiomycosis infection rate or death, while one study found it prevented infection and death (action 764). One study found that adding antifungal skin bacteria to soil significantly reduced chytridiomycosis infection rate of red-backed salamanders, and three studies found that adding antifungal skin bacteria to chytrid infected amphibians reduced weight loss (action 764). Treatment with antimicrobial skin peptides before or after infection did not significantly increase survival of common toads (action 764). Field treatment approaches show limited success, with one study finding that treating wild midwife toads with fungicide, along with pond drying, reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis (action 767). Immunization showed no effectiveness, with one study finding that vaccinating mountain yellow-legged frogs with formalin-killed chytrid fungus did not significantly reduce chytridiomycosis infection rate or mortality (action 765).", "action_ids": ["882","770","764","767","765"]}

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of retaining habitat features like riparian buffers, coarse woody debris, and snags during timber harvesting?
relevant_summary:
**Riparian Buffer Benefits:** Twelve studies investigated retaining riparian buffer strips during timber harvest for amphibians (action 747). Six studies found that amphibian abundance was significantly higher with buffers or had mixed effects depending on species and buffer width compared to clearcutting without buffers. Four studies found that abundance and species composition in buffered areas were similar to unharvested forest. Two studies found that wider riparian buffer strips resulted in greater numbers of amphibian species and abundance.

**Riparian Buffer Negative Impacts:** Two studies found that amphibian numbers and species were lower in riparian buffer areas than in unharvested forest (action 747). Six studies found mixed effects depending on species or volume of existing downed wood when comparing buffered areas to unharvested forest.

**Coarse Woody Debris Benefits:** Studies on leaving coarse woody debris in forests found that felled forest areas with woody debris had more small mammal species groups than areas without woody debris (action 2647). Two of three shrew species were more numerous in areas with increased volumes of coarse woody debris. When adding woody debris to landscapes, four of five studies found areas with added woody debris had similar or higher reptile species richness compared to areas with no added debris (action 3718). Two of six studies found areas with added woody debris had higher reptile abundance.

**Coarse Woody Debris Negative Impacts:** One study found that retaining or adding coarse woody debris did not increase numbers or frequency of records of small mammals (action 2647). One study found that pastures with added timber had lower abundance of rare reptile species compared to pastures without timber (action 3718). Regarding woody debris removal, one study found that debris removal increased understory vegetation cover, one found it increased young tree density, while another found it decreased young tree density (action 1213).

**Snags Benefits:** Studies on leaving standing deadwood/snags showed mixed results. One study found that adding snags and woody debris had mixed effects on reptile diversity, species richness, and abundance (action 3631). One study found areas with added woody debris (including snags) had higher reptile species richness than areas with no added debris (action 3718).

**Snags Negative Impacts:** Studies found that leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not result in higher salamander abundances compared to total clearcutting and did not prevent decreases in salamander abundance compared to no harvesting (action 845). One study found that increasing standing coarse woody debris had no effect on reptile diversity, species richness, and abundance (action 3631).

**Variable Retention Management Benefits:** A study found that nine bird species occurred at higher densities in stands under variable retention management compared to control stands (action 332). Patch retention harvesting contained more birds of more species than clearcut areas, retaining similar numbers to unharvested areas, and forest specialist species were found with greater frequency in patch retention plots (action 330).

query: What actions are available to mitigate the impacts of agricultural pollution on amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents reviewed, several types of actions are available to mitigate the impacts of agricultural pollution on amphibian populations. Reducing pesticide, herbicide or fertilizer use has shown positive effects, with one study in Taiwan finding that halting pesticide use along with habitat management increased a population of Taipei frogs (Action 832). Managing ditches can be effective, as one controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that managing ditches increased common toad numbers, and one replicated site comparison study in the Netherlands found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance was significantly higher in ditches managed under agri-environment schemes compared to those managed conventionally (Action 749). Creating wetlands may also help, with fifteen studies showing that created wetlands can provide suitable habitat for amphibians, though effectiveness varies based on wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands (Action 880). However, some actions show limited effectiveness or lack evidence - one replicated, controlled study in the USA found that planting buffer strips along streams did not increase amphibian abundance, numbers of species, or the ratio of adults to tadpoles (Action 819). Several other potentially relevant actions such as preventing pollution from agricultural lands entering watercourses (Action 802) and restricting herbicide, fungicide and pesticide use on and around ponds (Action 787) currently have no evidence for their effects on amphibian populations.

Five replicated studies (two also controlled and randomized) from three countries found no or mixed effects on birds, invertebrates and plants.
Five studies (three replicated controlled of which two randomized) from four countries found positive effects of reducing or stopping fertilizer applications on invertebrates, Eurasian skylark, or plants. Four studies (three replicated, controlled and randomized) from two countries found reducing or stopping fertilizer inputs had no, or no consistent effects on some invertebrates and farmland birds. Two studies from the UK (one replicated) found plots where fertilizer inputs were not reduced tended to have higher earthworm biomass or abundance.
Fifteen studies (three replicated controlled of which one also randomized, five site comparisons and one review) from seven countries looked at the effects of reducing or stopping applications of two or more inputs: pesticides, herbicides, or fertilizers. Thirteen studies found positive effects of reducing two or more inputs on some or all invertebrates, plants, soil organisms, and birds studied. Seven studies found negative or no effects of reducing combinations of inputs on some invertebrates, plants or birds."

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of creating wetlands for amphibians.
Five site comparison studies (including four replicated studies) in the USA compared created to natural wetlands and found that created wetlands had similar numbers of amphibian species, amphibian abundance or communities depending on depth as natural wetlands. Two of the studies found that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower abundance and different communities compared to natural wetlands. One site comparison study in the USA found that created wetlands had similar numbers of species to adjacent forest. One global review and two site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA combined created and restored wetlands and compared them to natural wetlands and found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance was higher or similar, or higher in 54% of studies and similar in 35% of studies reviewed compared to natural wetlands. Three site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA found that certain amphibian species were only found in created or natural wetlands. 
One before-and-after study in Australia found that captive-bred green and golden bell frog tadpoles released into a created wetland did not establish a self-sustaining population.
Five studies (including two replicated studies) in Kenya and the USA that investigated colonization of created wetlands found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized the wetlands. One global review and three studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and amphibian abundance in created wetlands were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands."

query: How effective are conservation actions such as legal protection, habitat creation, and translocation for great crested newt populations in the UK?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, conservation actions for great crested newts in the UK show mixed effectiveness. Regarding translocation, four of six studies found that translocated great crested newts maintained or established breeding populations, with populations present one year after release in 37% of cases (Action 858). However, one study found that breeding failed in 48% of ponds within three years, and one systematic review of 31 great crested newt studies found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including translocations resulted in self-sustaining populations (Action 858). For habitat creation, three studies found that great crested newts established breeding populations at 57-75% of created ponds, with up to 88% of created ponds being colonized by translocated or naturally colonizing newts (Action 863). However, a systematic review found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including pond creation resulted in self-sustaining populations (Action 863). Regarding pond restoration, one replicated controlled study found that pond restoration did not increase great crested newt populations, and a systematic review found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including pond restoration resulted in self-sustaining populations (Action 878). For legal protection, three reviews found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development, though the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued increased to over 600 in England and Wales over 10 years (Action 779). Additional habitat management including creating artificial hibernacula along with other terrestrial habitat management maintained great crested newt populations in one study (Action 759), and creating refugia along with other interventions maintained four populations (Action 772).

For habitat creation, three studies found that great crested newts established breeding populations at 57-75% of created ponds, with up to 88% of created ponds being colonized by translocated or naturally colonizing newts (Action 863). However, a systematic review found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including pond creation resulted in self-sustaining populations (Action 863). Regarding pond restoration, one replicated controlled study found that pond restoration did not increase great crested newt populations, and a systematic review found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including pond restoration resulted in self-sustaining populations (Action 878). For legal protection, three reviews found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development, though the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued increased to over 600 in England and Wales over 10 years (Action 779). Additional habitat management including creating artificial hibernacula along with other terrestrial habitat management maintained great crested newt populations in one study (Action 759), and creating refugia along with other interventions maintained four populations (Action 772).", "action_ids": ["858","863","779","878","759","772"]}

query: What is the evidence regarding the long-term success and timeframes for amphibian populations to respond to habitat restoration, such as replanting or vegetation clearance?
relevant_summary:
Evidence regarding long-term success and timeframes for amphibian populations responding to habitat restoration shows mixed results across different restoration approaches. For vegetation replanting, three studies in Australia, Canada and Spain found that amphibian abundance or community composition became more similar to natural sites with time since grassland reseeding, and one study in Australia found that numbers of frog species increased following restoration that included planting shrubs and trees (Action 849). However, one study in Canada found that following logging, amphibian abundance was lower or similar in forests that were planted and had herbicide treatment compared to those left to regenerate naturally, depending on species and forest age (Action 849).

For vegetation clearance, six studies in Australia, Estonia and the UK found that vegetation clearance increased numbers of frog species or increased, stabilized or maintained populations of natterjack toads (Action 761). However, one study in the UK found that vegetation clearance maintained a population of great crested newts for the first six years, but not in the longer term (Action 761).

Regarding pond restoration, six studies in Denmark, Estonia, Italy and the UK found that pond restoration increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and breeding success (Action 878). Three studies found that restored and created ponds were colonized by 1-7 species, with 6-65% of ponds colonized and 35% used for breeding (Action 878). For pond creation specifically, studies found that amphibians established stable populations in 50-100% of created ponds, and amphibians used 64-100% and reproduced in 64-68% of created ponds (Action 869).

For wetland restoration, eight out of ten site comparison studies in Canada and the USA found that amphibian abundance, numbers of species and species composition were similar between restored and natural wetlands (Action 879). A global review found that in 89% of cases, restored and created wetlands had similar or higher amphibian abundance or numbers of species compared to natural wetlands (Action 879). Three studies found that numbers of species in restored wetlands were affected by wetland size, proximity to source ponds and seasonality, but not wetland age (Action 879).

query: What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of different habitat management practices on agricultural land for amphibian conservation?
relevant_summary: The evidence shows that several habitat management practices on agricultural land demonstrate effectiveness for amphibian conservation. Creating ponds for amphibians is well-supported, with 28 studies finding that amphibians used some or all created ponds, and studies showing that amphibians established stable populations in 50-100% of created ponds and used 64-100% of created ponds for reproduction (Action 869). Managing ditches under agri-environment schemes significantly increased numbers of amphibian species and abundance compared to conventional management, with one study showing increased common toad numbers (Action 749). Financial incentives for farmers show promise, with three studies finding that payments to farmers created amphibian breeding habitat or increased frog or toad populations, and agri-environment schemes resulting in higher amphibian species numbers and abundance in ditches compared to conventional management (Action 818). Engaging landowners and volunteers in habitat management increased natterjack toad and Taipei frog populations, with individual programmes restoring up to 1,023 ponds or over 11,500 km² of habitat (Action 777). Pond restoration efforts had mixed but generally positive effects, with studies finding that pond restoration increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and breeding success, though effects varied by site and species (Action 878). Habitat connectivity restoration showed effectiveness, with one study finding that restoring connectivity between wetlands significantly decreased deaths of migrating amphibians (Action 840). However, evidence is lacking for some practices, with no studies found evaluating the effects of reduced tillage, preventing agricultural pollution, or creating natural habitat islands specifically for amphibian conservation (Actions 789, 802, 1425).

query: What management options are available to mitigate the impacts of timber harvesting on forest amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, several management options are available to mitigate the impacts of timber harvesting on forest amphibian populations. Retaining riparian buffer strips during timber harvest is a key strategy, with twelve studies investigating its effectiveness (Action 747). Six replicated and/or controlled studies found mixed effects on abundance depending on species and buffer width, with one finding significantly higher amphibian abundance with buffers. Eleven studies comparing amphibian numbers in forest with riparian buffers to unharvested forest found six studies showing mixed effects depending on species or volume of existing downed wood, four finding similar abundance and species composition to unharvested forest, and two finding lower numbers of species and abundance than unharvested forest. Additionally, two of four replicated studies found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance were greater in wider riparian buffer strips. Alternative harvesting methods can also be employed instead of clearcutting, including patch retention harvesting (Action 330), selective or reduced impact logging (Action 3867), harvesting groups of trees or using thinning (Action 3868), and shelterwood harvesting (Action 3871). However, the effectiveness data for these alternative harvesting methods comes primarily from studies on butterflies and moths rather than amphibians specifically. Managing silviculture practices in plantations (Action 792) is also mentioned as a relevant approach. Planting riparian buffer strips was tested in one replicated, controlled study in the USA which found it did not increase amphibian abundance, numbers of species, or the ratio of adults to tadpoles (Action 819).

Three studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of using shelterwood harvesting instead of clearcutting. All three studies were in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (3 studies): One controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that the species richness of macro-moths was higher after a forest was managed by shelterwood harvesting, than after harvest by patch-cutting or clearcutting, and the richness in the shelterwood harvested forest was similar to a thinned forest and an unharvested forest. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that forests managed by shelterwood harvesting had a similar species richness of moths to forests managed by single tree harvesting, group selection harvesting or clearcutting, but a lower species richness than unharvested forest. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that moth species richness recovered faster after shelterwood harvesting than after group selection harvesting or clearcutting.

POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that forests managed by group selection harvesting had a similar species richness of moths to forests managed by single tree harvesting or clearcutting, but a lower species richness than unharvested forest. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that moth species richness recovered at a similar rate after management by group selection harvesting or clearcutting, but recovery in both was slower than after shelterwood harvesting.

Four studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of using selective or reduced impact logging instead of conventional logging. Two studies were in Brazil and one was in each of Sweden and the USA.

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Brazil found that forests managed by reduced impact logging at different intensities had a different community composition of fruit-feeding butterflies to pristine forest.
Richness/diversity (3 studies): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that forests harvested by single tree selection had a similar species richness of moths to forests managed by group selection harvesting or clearcutting, but a lower species richness than unharvested forest. One site comparison study in Brazil found that a forest managed by reduced impact logging had a similar species richness and diversity of butterflies to primary forest. One replicated, site comparison study in Brazil found that forests managed by reduced impact logging at different intensities had a similar species richness of fruit-feeding butterflies.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (3 studies): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in Sweden found that selectively logged forests had a higher abundance of exposed moth caterpillars, but a similar abundance of concealed moth caterpillars, to clearcut forests, and a similar abundance of all moth caterpillars to undisturbed forests. One site comparison study in Brazil found that a forest managed by reduced impact logging had a higher abundance of butterflies than primary forest. One replicated, site comparison study in Brazil found that forests managed by reduced impact logging at intermediate intensity had a higher abundance of fruit-feeding butterflies than forests managed by high or low intensity reduced impact logging.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"

query: What are the most beneficial actions for creating or restoring aquatic habitats for amphibians?
relevant_summary: The most beneficial actions for creating or restoring aquatic habitats for amphibians include pond creation, pond restoration, wetland creation and restoration, and specific pond management techniques. Creating ponds for amphibians is highly effective, with all 28 studies finding that amphibians used some or all created ponds, and amphibians established stable populations in 50-100% of created ponds (Action 869). Created ponds were used or colonized by up to 15 naturally colonizing species and up to 10 species that reproduced (Action 869). Pond restoration is also beneficial, with studies showing that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and breeding success (Action 878). Wetland restoration proves effective, with restored wetlands having similar or higher amphibian abundance or numbers of species compared to natural wetlands in 89% of cases (Action 879). Creating wetlands results in similar numbers of amphibian species and abundance as natural wetlands, with four to 15 amphibian species using or colonizing created wetlands (Action 880). Specific pond management techniques include deepening, de-silting or re-profiling ponds, which resulted in establishment of breeding populations and increased populations of various amphibian species (Action 817). Regulating water levels helps maintain amphibian populations, with maintaining pond water levels enabling successful breeding (Action 833). Removing or controlling fish by drying out ponds increased numbers of amphibian species and breeding success (Action 826). Success factors for aquatic habitat creation include considerations of pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds, presence of fish, wetland size, proximity to source ponds, and wetland design (Actions 869, 880).

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of using chemical treatments for amphibian conservation?
relevant_summary: Chemical treatments for amphibian conservation show both beneficial and negative effects according to documented studies. Benefits include: twelve of sixteen studies found that antifungal treatment cured or increased survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis, with four studies finding that treatments reduced infection levels (Action 882). Six of eight studies testing itraconazole specifically found it effective at curing amphibians of chytridiomycosis, with one study showing it reduced infection levels (Action 882). One study found that salt addition to a pond kept green and golden bell frogs free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months (Action 762). Pond drying and fungicidal treatment of midwife toads reduced infection levels though did not eradicate chytridiomycosis (Actions 766, 767). Negative impacts documented include: six studies found that specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians (Action 882). Antifungal skin bacteria treatments showed mixed results, with three of four studies finding they did not reduce chytridiomycosis infection rate or death in salamanders or frogs, though one study found prevention of infection and death (Action 764). Treatment with antimicrobial skin peptides did not significantly increase survival of common toads (Action 764).

query: As an alternative to treating infected individuals, what environmental management actions can help control chytridiomycosis in the wild?
relevant_summary: Environmental management actions for controlling chytridiomycosis in the wild include modifying pond chemistry and physical environments. Adding salt to ponds has shown promise, with one study in Australia finding that following addition of salt to a pond containing the chytrid fungus, a population of green and golden bell frogs remained free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months (Action 762). Direct removal of the chytrid fungus from ponds through pond drying and fungicidal treatment was tested in one study in Mallorca, which found that these methods reduced levels of infection in resident midwife toads but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis (Action 766). Prevention measures include sterilizing equipment when moving between amphibian sites to prevent disease spread, although no evidence was found for the effects of this practice on disease transmission between populations (Action 768). Other proposed environmental approaches lack evidence for their effectiveness, including using zooplankton to remove chytrid zoospores (Action 800), preventing heavy usage or excluding wildfowl from aquatic habitat (Action 799), and preventing pollution from agricultural lands or sewage treatment facilities entering watercourses (Action 802). Trade regulation has been shown to be effective for population recovery from over-exploitation, with one review finding that reducing trade in two frog species through legislation allowed populations to recover (Action 824).
